entries.title: Data::Dumper::GUI
entries.text: Have you ever dealt with data structures that were too large to fit in your screen? Or do you have 1024 inch screen? Toby Inkster created a module that you can use as a simple replacement of Data::Dumper inside your code, and that will open a window, a real desktop GUI window(!) where you can drill down in your data structure. After installing the module you could already try it with this statement as well:   perl -MData::Dumper::GUI -e ' Dumper {%INC}' to see which modules are loaded by perl and by Data::Dumper::GUI together.

entries.title: jam - glue between pinto and scm
entries.text: I am not entirely sure I like that instead of adding a feature to an existing project, people create a new tool because one feature was missing. OTOH, I love the fact that people are creating solutions to problems, so let's see what Alexey Melezhik builds.

entries.title: Retry failed Gearman jobs
entries.text: Gearman manages your computational tasks and hands them out to available workers. It can do it in a fault tolerant way. Sebastian Willing is showing us how to retry failed jobs.

entries.title: Arrays vs. Lists in Perl: What's the Difference?
entries.text: Mike Friedman provides a detailed explanation to the phenomenon. I think one of the commenters put it quite right, that basically lists are 'array literals'. There are of course differences, just as there are differences betwee $x and a string 'abcd' you could put in that scalar variable. (OK, betweeen lists and arrays there might be a few more edge cases.)

entries.title: The grep test - my personal experience
entries.text: The grep test basically means that you should be able to grep for any meaningful string in your code base to find out the usage of those keywords. This sounds like a very reasonable approach and a good way to explain it, but what would you do if you had a piece of code where you get the name of a method passed to you and you call that method using the variable name? How can the name of that method grepped?

entries.title: Fiddling with the metacpan.org URLs
entries.text: Olaf Alders, the leader of the Meta::CPAN projects asks your input on how the URLs on MetaCPAN.org should look like. As this is one of the most important web sites for any Perl user, you should probably take a look at the issue. In a nutshell, what should be the fixed URL of a script supplied in a CPAN package?

entries.title: Fennec V2.x - Testing made better
entries.text: Chad Granum has released the second version of his test module. It is a testing framework built on top of Test::More and Test::Builder so it is familiar to you. It looks like something I should try.

entries.title: Crowdsourcing self-confidence
entries.text: Ribasushi (aka. Peter Rabbitson) the leader of the DBIx::Class project provides a rare glimpse into the world of open source project management. The frustration, the doubt and and the hope. As it turns out, it is not just code. There are real people behind theses things.

entries.title: There are no Perl events in my country/city...
entries.text: A couple of days ago I saw one of the bloggers complaining about the above. I could not stop myself from writing this.

entries.title: p2 progress
entries.text: p2 or p11 is one of the efforts, primarily of Reini Urban, to create a Virtual Machine that can run both Perl 5 and Perl 6. His current plan is to be able to parse 50% of the Per 5 syntax by the end of the summer. (He lives in a place where the summer is long.)

entries.title: Roles in p5-MOP
entries.text: MOP is the meta-object protocol behhind Moose. p5-MOP is the renewed(!) effort of Stevan Little, the author of Moose, to integrate MOP into the core of perl. In the last couple of weeks he made a lot of progress that you can see in his articles.

entries.title: p5-MOP gets p6 style traits (sorta)
entries.text: Another article by Stevan Little about the p5-MOP progress. If you'd like to get involved, you need to do it quickly! Before he finishes the whole implementation.

entries.title: Scala for Perl 5 Programmers
entries.text: Not only has Garu (aka. Breno G. de Oliveira) learnt programming in Scala, he also went all the way and prepared a Scala tutorial especially for people with Perl 5 programming background. Oh, and if you'd like to know why to learn Scala: if for nothing else, to be able to contribute to the Moe project. If that isn't interesting to you, then consider the fact that learning foreign languages improves the way you express yourself in your own language.

entries.text: Ovid interviewed JT Smith, creator of the Lacuna Expanse and a few other Perl-based businesses. The written interview covers both the architecture of web-based application, and answers the question 'Why did they use Perl?'

entries.title: APIs and Marketing
entries.text: A short note from JT why building an API is also good for marketing.

entries.title: All about Perl 6 – interview of Jonathan Worthington (Part 2 of 3)
entries.text: So how does the JVM backend and the new MoarVM backend relate to each other, and why did they keep the development of MoarVM secret? How will Perl 5 interoperate with Perl 6 on top of the MoarVM?

entries.title: Warning when something goes wrong
entries.text: How to print to the standard error (STDERR) and how to use the warn() function.

entries.title: Bare Here documents are deprecated - How to find offending code?
entries.text: What do you think are bare here-documents? I am still not sure, but apparently there are bare onces and barer ones. The latter is gone from perl while the former stays. In the original version of this post I explained how to track down the bare here-documents, but after some detective work done by others, I had to updated the article. So now it contains both the bare and the barer ones.
